title-group.article-title: The Abolition of the Pensions 'Earnings Rule'

p.mixed-citation: These rates were also changed from 1 October 1989 in the reforms to National Insurance introduced in the 1989 Budget and described in Dilnot and Webb (1989).
The rules for this system and the value and extent of entitlements are detailed in Social Security Statistics and Fry, Smith and White (1990).

The propensity for many pensioners to save, motivated either by a desire to bequest or the need to cover unforeseen liabilities, may imply that future income has a value. However, the individual may well be better off receiving the pension now and saving it than saving through the state pension scheme.

This result is somewhat sensitive to the choice of discount rate — the value of the deferred pension compared with the annual pension varies between 59 and 77 per cent as the discount rate varies between 1 and 5 per cent.

The increase in the earnings rule limit and the decline in the activity rate among pensioners have eliminated much of the impact. In its 1967 Report, the National Insurance Advisory Committee found that 20,000 were subject to the provisions of the rule, and that there was substantial bunching below the then £5 per week earnings limit.
